Award.AwardTitle: Robust Nonlinear Adaptive Control of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Using Neural Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop and experimentally validate robust nonlinear adaptive controllers for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) using neural networks. The approach is to use both pre-trained and on-line neural networks based on multilayer perceptrons. The concept of dynamic nonlinear damping will be applied to modify the adaptation law to increase the robustness in the presence of unmodeled dynamics. A stable weight adjustment rule for the on-line neural network will be derived using a Lyapunov stability theorem.

Intellectual Merit
This research, through the use of adaptive controllers, will increase the robustness of UAV operations. The lack of robustness has limited the use of UAVs, despite their potential to replace manned vehicles for many types of missions. Also, as the level of UAV autonomy increases, it is important to design controllers that can work in the entire flight envelope. This research will involve an interdisciplinary team of faculty members from the Engineering and Computer Science Departments at Cal Poly Pomona. An existing fleet of UAVs and complimentary resources will be used.

Broader Impact
Increased UAV robustness will have potential to extend and increase the use of UAVs for rescue missions, border patrol, scientific research, etc., which will have a significant positive impact on society. This research will involve a number of undergraduate and underrepresented students. This research will also be helpful in curriculum improvement. Moreover, this project will help enhance the research capability of the University, a Hispanic Serving and Designated Undergraduate Institution. Research results will be disseminated to the Intelligent Systems community via conference presentations and publication in journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the use of various types of neural networks for the robust nonlinear adaptive control of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The lack of robustness and autonomy has limited the use of UAVs, despite their potential to replace manned aircraft for widespread applications. Conventional controllers based on linearized flight dynamics model work for particular flight conditions. Nonlinear controllers using dynamic inversion technique requires accurate modeling of flight vehicles. However, it’s difficult to obtain a model of aircraft that can capture all the dynamics. Neural networks can map any general nonlinear function using input/output pair collected during flight tests, thus eliminating the need of extensive modeling. Nonlinear controllers based on neural networks can increase robustness and UAV autonomy, thereby helping utilize full potential of the UAVs. Increased autonomy and robustness also helps safe integration of UAVs in the National Airspace System (NAS).

UAVs are the fastest growing sector of Aerospace Industry. However, because of lack of desired level of autonomy and robustness, their operation is limited. In order to utilize their full potential, they must be integrated into the National Airspace System. The integration requires increased autonomy, ability to operate in wider flight envelope, and ability to handle unforeseen circumstances such as damage of a component during flight and presence of heavy wind. This is also important for increased use of UAVs for various applications such as search and rescue missions, surveillance of fire-, earthquake-, and flood-affected areas, aerial photography, traffic monitoring, 3-D mapping, vegetation growth analysis, etc. Increased use of UAVs for these applications will have significant impact on society. UAVs are significantly cheaper than manned counterparts. Increased use of UAVs reduces the cost for number of missions, thereby helping reduce the government spending at local, state, and federal levels. Intelligent and robust controllers assure safety of operations, and increase acceptability of these vehicles to society.

We have used different types of neural networks for intelligent control of UAVs, verified the controllers using flight data, and tested in the software-in-the-loop simulations. We will continue this line of research in furthering this technology as it is very important that UAVs are intelligent enough to safely maneuver autonomously in the airspace in the event of unforeseen circumstances. 

This research significantly involved a diverse group of our undergraduate and graduate students including underrepresented students. This helped us expose our students to state-of-the-art in UAV technologies, thereby helping prepare strong workforce for the industry, academia, and Government. This is particularly important as the aerospace industry is facing aging workforce and there is need to prepare well-trained graduates that can take higher level of responsibility than entry level graduates usually do.  The students worked in a multidisciplinary team (s) under the supervision of faculty members from different departments within the Colleges of Engineering and Science. The project helped enhance the research capability of our university, which is one of the Hispanic Serving Institutions in the country with the population of Hispanic students at 34%.  It also helped promote the culture of interdisciplinary research at the university, which is gradually transforming itself into research institution from a primarily teaching-oriented undergraduate institution.
